Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Research at Michigan State University to Push the Intensity Frontier and Support Accelerator Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will push the frontier in intensity of ion beams produced by superconducting ion accelerators. High accelerator performance requires a bright, continuous source of ions, and for that ion accelerators typically use sources of high-charge-state ions which can be efficiently accelerated. Such sources, called Electron Cyclotron Resonance or ECR sources, are complex with rich physics to be explored. In this project, factors leading to unreliable ECR source operation will be studied. Diagnostics will systematically gather information to better understand, mitigate, and control reliability issues. This research will be carried out at Michigan State University, where it will help to improve performance of existing ion sources. This project will train one PhD graduate student in accelerator physics technology.

To maintain a stable and compact beam phase-space for reliable machine operation of continuous wave superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) linacs, ECR sources must continuously inject ion beams with low drifts and stable output. In this project, ECR sources at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) will be instrumented to measure correlations of temperature in key system components with the current output. A data logging system will be developed, drift correlations identified, and mitigations will be tested. Fast plasma instabilities are also observed in high intensity ECR operation and can lead to ~25% or more oscillations in beam current with potential machine damage. These instabilities will be studied with the FRIB and NSCL sources using higher-charge-state ions, where understanding of the instability will be improved through analytical studies, development of simple parametric models, and synergetic collaboration with other research groups. The timeline of the project will cover three years and is consistent with early commissioning activities on the FRIB front-end and leverages FRIB hardware.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Particle accelerators have many applications, whether for fundamental research or in industry. Accelerating heavy ions helps the nuclear science community study nuclear processes associated with short-lived isotopes not normally found on Earth. Doing so provides insight into new nuclear physics while developing our knowledge on topics ranging from the structure of the nucleus and nuclear astrophysics. Rare isotopes also have many societal applications ranging from medicine, material science, and homeland security. In the US, the Coupled Cyclotron Facility (CCF) and soon the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), both on the campus of Michigan State University, are central to furthering our understanding of rare isotopes. At the heart of any heavy ion accelerator is an ion source, whose performance ultimately determines the maximum available beam power that the accelerator can produce. Higher beam power corresponds to more experimental events and production. High-quality sources producing a compact beam that can be efficiently accelerated are key to facility performance. Electron Cyclotron Resonance (ECR) Ion Sources are unique ion sources that can deliver high currents of high charge-state ion beams. The high-charge state ions help to make the acceleration process more cost-efficient. The ion source's performance directly impacts the accelerator's performance and availability and is, therefore, an essential component of it. However, this also means that an unstable ion source can negatively affect the operation of the accelerator facility and limit its users' productivity.

The result obtained from this grant provided insight into instabilities that occur in an ECR ion source plasma and how they affect the device's performance. Additionally, this grant's outcomes include the development of a new set of charged particle diagnostics used to study and characterize the ion source instabilities. The results showed that high energy electrons, and their diffusion out of the plasma, are correlated with the instabilities. Measuring the distributions of diﬀusing electrons and ions extracted from the source during unstable operation improved our understanding of the dynamics of the plasma. These measurements showed how critical the profile of the axial magnetic field is in the diffusion of high energy electrons and, therefore, in generating instabilities. Two magnetic field components play a crucial role in this effect: the minimum of the ion source magnetic field and the magnetic field maximum near the system’s extraction region. These aspects of the magnetic field impact the energy and intensity of electrons that diffuse out of the ion source.  Results from this grant will help guide the optimal design of magnetic field profiles for future ECR ion sources to enable stable operation at high intensities. The design of the ECR magnetic field profile will be very important for the next generation of ECR ion sources, such as those that operate beyond 28 GHz and will support state of the art facility accelerators such as the Electron-Ion Collider (EIC).

Finally, this grant supported the research of a Ph.D. student, Bryan Isherwood. His Ph.D. thesis at MSU (August 2020) summarizes research advances made. The project served as training in accelerator science which Bryan will now leverage in his career.
